lines.text: Do you like her?
Well, I just said I...

No, no. You just said you loved her. There's some difference between lovin' and likin'. When I married Jennie's mother, I-I didn't love her - I liked her... I liked her a lot. I liked Martha for at least three years after we were married and then one day it just dawned on me I loved her. I still do... still do. You see, Sam, when you love a woman without likin' her, the night can be long and cold, and contempt comes up with the sun.
[the family is saying grace]

Lord, we cleared this land. We plowed it, sowed it, and harvest it. We cook the harvest. It wouldn't be here and we wouldn't be eating it if we hadn't done it all ourselves. We worked dog-bone hard for every crumb and morsel, but we thank you Lord just the same for the food we're about to eat, amen.
[at the site of his wife's grave]

I don't even know what to say to you any more, Martha. There's not much I can tell you about this war. It's like all wars, I guess. The undertakers are winning. And the politicians who talk about the glory of it. And the old men who talk about the need of it. And the soldiers, well, they just wanna go home. I guess you're not so lonely any more, with Ann and James and Jacob. And maybe the boy. You didn't know Ann, did you? Well, you'd like her. You'd like her, Martha. Why, she and James are so much alike, they're just like... no... no... we were never that much alike, were we Martha? We just sorta grew alike through the years. But I wish, I wish I could just know what you're thinking about it all, Martha. And maybe it wouldn't seem so bad to me if I knew what you thought about it.
[He notices the church bells are ringing]
You never give up, do you?
What do you do with dead soldiers?
Jacob, you look like you got somthin' on your mind. Go ahead, say what you think.
We've been through it all before.

Now now, don't pat around with me. You were raised to say what you think. You were all raised to say what you think. If there's anything I can't stand, it's a lot of noisy silence. Now, come on, let's have some talkin' here.
[Jacob stands up]
Well, if you're going to make a speech, I'm sorry I said it.
I was talking to Henry.
Sir?
Well, what do you think?
Well, no sir, I wouldn't.
Why not?
I don't see any reason to fight for something I don't believe is right and I don't think a real friend would ask me to.
Can you give me one good reason why I should let my sons march down that road like a bunch of damn fools?
Virginia needs all her sons, Mr. Anderson.
They don't belong to the state they belong to ME! When they were babies I never saw the state comin' around here with a spare tit!

I wanna say somethin'. I've known since the train that we weren't liable to find him. It was just a hair of a chance that we got Sam back. I knew that. Maybe I knew even before we left home, but somehow I just had to try! And if we don't try, we don't do. And if we don't do, why are we here on this earth?
You can't do that! You can't burn my train!
Maybe not, but you gotta give me credit for tryin'!
But why? Why?
It's not the kind of train I favor.
[during a battle]
I never seen nobody get so peevish over a cow before
When are you going to take this war seriously, Anderson?

Now let me tell you something, Johnson, before you get on my wrong side. My corn I take seriously, because it's mine. And my potatoes and tomatoes and my fence I take note of because they're mine. But this war is not mine and I don't take note of it.

I know how you feel about this war, Pa. I guess we more or less feel the same way, but I don't see how we can sit by and ignore it anymore. Now you say it's not our business, not our fight, but we're Virginians and I believe that anything that concerns Virginia concerns us.
John...
Sir?
What are you going to do? You gonna keep your slaves or let them go free?
You know I don't have any slaves, Pa.
That's right, John, you don't have a slave to your name, do you.
Suppose you had a friend that owned slaves and suppose somebody was going to come and take them away from him. Would you help him - fight to help him keep them?
No sir!
Your name's Nathan, isn't it?
You know my name, Pa.
I seem to remember something about...
Why we have this same conversation every Saturday before Sunday meeting, I'll never know, but I'm going to pray to the Almighty that this will be the end of it.
[pouring whiskey to celebrate the birth of his granddaughter]
How old are you now, Boy?
Eighteen, sir.
That means you'll be twenty in four years. Eighteen to you, sixteen to me.
Just a little bit, sir. I've never tasted it.
Well, that's no good reason at all. I've known men who've been drinkin' hard and steady all their lives that have never tasted it, either.
If your son is among these prisoners, you're too late. There's a war going on, Mr. Anderson. Sergeant!
Sir?
Lock 'em up.
Alright, lock 'em up!

[to Anderson]
We have schedules to keep.
[in order to rescue Boy, the Andersons have captured the Union POW train]
You're the man who's looking for his son.
And you're the man with schedules to keep.
[Sam has ordered his men to go home]
I had no right to tell him that, but these men can't go through another fight. We knew before we went into the last one we couldn't win.
Then why'd you do it, Sam?
Easier than runnin', I gues.
You can have your chance tonight, if you want to take it.
Chance for what?

To run. They don't waste men on prisoner duty and they're usually the worst of the lot. They plan on herdin' us onto that sternwheeler and some of us don't fancy no sightseein' tour up North. When they open that gate tonight, you stay as close to me as a flea on a hound dog. Somethin' else. Once we get goin', you're on your own. I gotta forget you ain't nothin' but a lap baby.
Mr. Anderson, if you can sit in the middle of this war and not get touched, I congratulate you.
husbands like to be alone once in awhile.
Why?

You never know why, but I can always tell when James wants to be alone. A mood comes over him. I can always see it in his eyes before it gets there. I don't know where the mood comes from or why, but that's when I leave him alone. It seems sometimes things get so fickle in a man that he comes to feel that everything is closing in on him - and that's when he wants to be left alone. You understand, don't you?
No!
That fella, Tinkham - he's the only man I know that started at the bottom and went down in the world. He'd steal horses for nothing and now he gets paid for it.
It's no easy job, Sam, to take care of a woman.
No, sir.

They expect things they never ask for. And when they don't get them, they ask you why. Sometimes they don't ask... and just go ahead and punish you for not doing something you didn't know you were supposed to do in the first place.
[first lines]
They come closer every day, Pa.
They on our land?
No, sir.
Then it doesn't concern us... does it?
[Boy Anderson is wearing a confederate cap]
Where'd you get the hat, boy?
Down by the creek, sir.
Some fella down there handing out hats?
What about you, James? You ever think you might like to own a slave?
Well, I guess I never thought about it, Pa.
Well, think about it! Think about it! If you had money would you go out and buy a slave?
No sir, I wouldn't.
Why not?
Well, if I can't do my own work with my own hands it'd never get done.
[at the site of Charlie's wife's grave]
You still miss her, don't you?

Jennie, you don't know how I feel. Even after all these years, 16 years gone, 16 years. And even so, I somehow feel that she's not really dead but just resting. And it's as though I'm expecting her to get up and walk home with me.
There are no doubt some present, Charlie Anderson, who wonder why you and yours are never on time for the Lord's services.
Have I kept the Lord waiting, Pastor Bjoerling?
You have not.
[all laugh]
What'd I do?

It's what you haven't done, boy. A man who eats with his hat on is going nowhere in a hurry. Now, your mother wanted you all raised as good Christians, and I may not be able to do that thorny job as well as she could, but I can do something about your manners.
I'd be eternally grateful if you'd permit me to call upon you this evening.
Eternally is a long time, Sam.
Not when one carries a memory of you, Miss Jennie.
Charlie Anderson, I wonder if you'd be good enough to tell me why you even bother coming to services. Meaning no disrespect, of course.
It was my wife's last request, Pastor Bjoerling. Meaning no disrespect, of course.
I'm glad you're here, Johnson. I've been meaning to have a word with your people about those cannons of yours. The chickens have stopped laying, the cows have dried up. Who do I send the bill to?

[to the engineer, explaining the decision to burn the prison bound train]
You run a sad kind of a train, mister. You take people away when they don't want to go and won't bring them back when they're ready.

[a young Confederate picket has just shot one of Anderson's sons]
Dead. Dead! How old are you? How old?
Sixteen.

[In a rage, but restraining himself]
Six - Sixteen. I'm not gonna' kill you. I want you to live! I want you to live to be an old man. And I want you to have many... many, many children. And I want you to feel about your children then... the way I feel about mine now! And someday, when a man comes along and kills one of 'em, I want you to remember! I want you to remember.
These are my sons. They don't belong to the state. When they were babies, I never saw the state coming around with a spare teat. We never asked anything of the state and never expected anything.
I don't know what to say. I mean... Well, I know what to say, I just don't know how.
It must be all very complicated, then.

No, it's, uh, just all memorized. Everything I wanted to say I've said a dozen times before I got here. I said it to my horse and it sounded good. I said it again to the trees ans it sounded better. I said it to the moon and it sounded perfect.
The moon can't hear you, Sam. He smiles and smiles, but he never hears. I do.
[noticing porch audience they walk further on]
Is that a Confederate cow or a Union cow?
That must be a Union cow, sir.
Union cow's tasty?
Quite tasty, sir.
Then take her prisoner...
It's late Gabriel won't Mr. Abernathy be looking for you?
He gone Missy, gone to Richmond left the Field boss in charge.
Well won't he be wondering where you are?
Old Jethro don't care nothing about me! When my Momma died he even took our cabin. I don't have to go back do I Missy? Man said I'm free! Don't that mean I don't got to go back?
Well if the man said your free Gabriel I guess that means you can go any where in the world you want to go!
You mean I just walk on down that rode and keep on walking?
You can run if you like Gabriel!
Goodbye Missy.
